Cheim & Read 521 West 23rd Street, Chelsea Through Oct. 21

After a visit to Eastern Europe and the Nazi death camps in 1988, Louise Fishman's Abstract Expressionist-style painting took on a harsh, grayed-down sobriety, as if painting had become a process of mourning or penance for her. Looking at her new works, you wonder if some other significant experience -- a visit, say, to Giverny -- had awakened Ms. Fishman to new possibilities of pleasure.

Her painting is still tough and gritty in its bluntly gestural, grid-based physicality, but now it has a lusciousness of color that verges on the hedonistic. ''A Stranger,'' with its web of impulsively made, wide slate gray lines over a radiant salmon pink field, is an unabashedly voluptuous yet still excitingly raw picture.

Ms. Fishman's works are not what you would call serene. Each heavily layered, extensively reworked picture feels like a hard-fought standoff between forces of order and chaos. In ''That Iron String,'' thick gray swatches are troweled on in a grid formation over a swirling space of incandescent green and black, into which lines have been randomly scrawled with the wooden end of the brush: harmony is animated by a bracing dissonance.

Some paintings, like ''Flying Solo,'' with its soft allover patchwork of Impressionistic color, lack the feeling of conflicted urgency that activates the most arresting works, but this show as a whole brings an exhilarating restlessness and openness to the traditional practice of modernist abstraction.
